word.entryDescription: a place of higher or specialised education for students who have left school
word.entryExample: After school I spent three years at college.

word.entryDescription: red, blue, green, yellow, etc
word.entryExample: What colour are your eyes?

word.entryDescription: full of bright colours or having many different colours
word.entryExample: It's a very colourful place near the beach, and there are lots of boats.

word.entryDescription: to arrive at home
word.entryExample: Children, come home now, it is starting to rain.

word.entryDescription: to appear, usually after being in/inside/under something, or to develop from something
word.entryExample: The school is only five minutes' walk from where we come out of the underground station.

word.entryDescription: (for a situation that requires attention) to appear unexpectedly
word.entryExample: A failure message came up on the screen.

word.entryDescription: a film which is supposed to make you laugh
word.entryExample: Shall we go to see a comedy or an action film?

word.entryDescription: providing a pleasant or relaxing feeling
word.entryExample: The walking boots must be comfortable.

word.entryDescription: (=comic book) a magazine of stories told in pictures with only a little writing
word.entryExample: I'm reading this comic about a superhero but it's boring.

word.entryDescription: (=comic) a magazine full of cartoon stories
word.entryExample: Jill wants to read the comic book.

word.entryDescription: an expert on a particular subject who talks or writes about it on television, radio or in a newspaper; or someone on television or radio describing an event as it is happening
word.entryExample: The commentator mentioned possible dangers.

word.entryDescription: officially asked to create something or to do a task for somebody
word.entryExample: The aim of Route 66 when commissioned in 1926 was to make use of as many stretches of existing road as possible.

word.entryDescription: to do something wrong or illegal
word.entryExample: A criminal is a person who commits a crime.

word.entryDescription: to exchange information with other people
word.entryExample: Doctors receive a lot of training in how to communicate with patients.

word.entryDescription: a group of people living in the same area, or a group of people who are similar in some way
word.entryExample: She earns huge respect in the community.

word.entryDescription: a group of animals or plants living in the same environment
word.entryExample: Rainforest communities are very biologically diverse.

word.entryDescription: to travel regularly between home and work, often a long way
word.entryExample: These days people are prepared more than ever to commute long distances to get to work.

word.entryDescription: closely packed together or neatly fitted into a limited space
word.entryExample: The apartment is very compact.

word.entryDescription: a business organisation
word.entryExample: Do you work for a large company?

word.entryDescription: describes an adjective or adverb when it is in a form which expresses the size, amount, degree, etc of one thing in relation to another thing
word.entryExample: Make sure you use comparative and superlative forms correctly.

word.entryDescription: a device with a needle that always points north, used for finding direction
word.entryExample: Do you know how to use a compass?

word.entryDescription: to do something to recognise the harm or damage caused to something
word.entryExample: You will be adequately compensated for your time and trouble.

word.entryDescription: an event in which you try to win something
word.entryExample: There's a competition with Greenfield school and I need some students to take part.

word.entryDescription: offering quality goods or services at attractive prices or determined to be more successful than other people/businesses
word.entryExample: Airline prices can be competitive and night flights are generally cheaper.

word.entryDescription: to say that you are not happy with something
word.entryExample: Yes! I want to complain! I'm returning these. I bought them last week and now they're broken.
It is painted completely white inside.

word.entryDescription: a comment which expresses admiration
word.entryExample: What a lovely meal – my compliments to the chef!

word.entryDescription: to follow an order, rule, etc
word.entryExample: While on the building site you must comply with the regulations by wearing a hard hat.

word.entryDescription: somebody who writes music
word.entryExample: Beethoven was a German composer.

word.entryDescription: plant material which is collected and left to decay so that it can be used to improve soil quality
word.entryExample: Organic waste, such as apple core, decompose and make a compost you can use in your garden.

word.entryDescription: made flat by squeezing or pressing
word.entryExample: Remains of plants and animals that lived hundreds of millions of years ago have gradually become buried and compressed under the Earth's surface and transformed into coal, oil and gas.

word.entryDescription: a machine that you use to store information, communicate and use programs
word.entryExample: I use my computer everyday.

word.entryDescription: a game you can play on a computer
word.entryExample: Robot plays computer games with Lucy.

word.entryDescription: the part of a computer on which you see pictures or information
word.entryExample: I'd get very depressed, if I had to stay at home all day in front of a computer screen!

word.entryDescription: to direct your attention towards something you are doing
word.entryExample: Try to concentrate so that you can keep up with what's going on in class.

word.entryDescription: to spend more time on or give more attention to one particular thing than others
word.entryExample: He always concentrated on social issues, because he found it easiest to write about things that upset him.

word.entryDescription: the amount of a substance in something
word.entryExample: The concentration of carbon dioxide in the Earth's atmosphere is increasing.

word.entryDescription: the ability to keep your thoughts or attention on something for a time without turning to something else
word.entryExample: Lack of sleep can have bad effects on your concentration, mood and performance.

word.entryDescription: an idea or plan
word.entryExample: The architect was aiming to recreate the concept of living in a tree.

word.entryDescription: worried about something
word.entryExample: I'm very concerned that we cannot do enough in time to provide the water that these new homes will need.

word.entryDescription: an event at which music is performed
word.entryExample: Emma is going to a Beyoncé concert.

word.entryDescription: to end a meeting, book, event, speech, etc by doing or saying one final thing
word.entryExample: To conclude, in my opinion, this last argument is the most important.

word.entryDescription: the end or final part of something such as a speech or a piece of writing
word.entryExample: Don't forget to give your conclusion!

word.entryDescription: to say that you strongly disapprove of something or that something is morally wrong
word.entryExample: I won't condemn his behaviour until I know all the facts.

word.entryDescription: how good or bad a physical state something is in
word.entryExample: You made sure the hospital was clean however bad the conditions were.

word.entryDescription: a sentence or clause beginning with "if" or "unless" and expressing a condition
word.entryExample: We use the first conditional when we talk about possible situations.

word.entryDescription: past simple form of 'confess' – to admit to something bad, wrong or illegal that you have done, that you feel, etc
word.entryExample: She confessed she had forgotten all about it.

word.entryDescription: to show or say that something is true, or to make an arrangement certain
word.entryExample: This has never been confirmed.

word.entryDescription: strong disagreement or fighting between people, groups, countries, etc
word.entryExample: There is less conflict in Africa than there used to be.

word.entryDescription: unable to understand or think clearly what is happening or what somebody is saying
word.entryExample: William is confused because he doesn't understand why Kate and Emma aren't getting on.
